Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2010 02:50AM jdootoo wrote: I had a needle biopsy done before surgery and it came back negative for lymph nodes. However, when I woke up after my BMX, I found out I had 6/7 positive nodes. My BS explained how they take out the auxillary node first, quick freeze it, do a biopsy, then proceed from there. When I went back in for my follow up appointment, she recommended a PET scan, which showed a very small amount of cancerous cells in the lymph nodes. She said that the radiation should wipe that out. I do not think your surgeon will want to take out all of your nodes, research has advanced us past those days. If he/she wants to do this, I would get a second opinion. Best of luck! One love, Jackie

My BS did an ultrasound and the lumps looked so much like lymph nodes that she called in a colleague to look at them. They ended up doing a biopsy, and they turned out to be fatty necrosis. Best of luck!
Posts.Title: Lymph Nodes in Lower Forearm???? jramick jramick

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 08:14AM jdootoo wrote: BobbiMarie, I was staged at IIIA so, even though I really did not want to do chemo, I knew that it would increase my survival rate significantly, and with 2 small children, I knew I had to do it. I think about what my OBGYN told me while I was pregnant when I asked her if I could drink an occasional glass of wine. She told me that it was probably fine, but if I did drink alchohol while pregnant and something was wrong with the baby, I may always wonder if I had caused the problem. That made my mind up for me right there. I approached chemo the same way, I just wanted to be sure that I have done everything that I can. I had my last THC treatment a year ago and, all in all, it was not nearly as bad as I thought it would be. Neuropathy was not a problem for me and I feel back to normal today other than having a mild case of LE. I know it is a tough decision and you need to do what is right for you. Love and hugs... One love, Jackie
Posts.Title: Chemo - since I have a choice, why would I? BobbiMarie Lee7

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2011 10:21AM jdootoo wrote: When I went in for surgery, I thought my nodes were clear because the biopsy came back negative. However, they removed 6 positive nodes with a 3cm tumor and nodes clumped together. Because of this, I had a PET scan following surgery and there was some uptake in the remaining nodes. Chemo and rads wiped out any remaining cancer cells and I think that is usually the case. Hugs and prayers to your wife. One love, Jackie
Posts.Title: CANCER IN LYMPH NODES many many

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2011 08:04PM jdootoo wrote: geocachelinda: When I went in for my interview (several months and a few phone calls after I applied online) i brought every piece of paper I could find! It is good that you applied in July since there is a 5 month waiting period. Since you are stage 3C, you are automatically qualified, whether or not you have to fight for it a little.  I agree with what Lisa said, once they meet you and see that you are legit, they are much more likely to take you seriously and speed up the process. One other thing that I did was to speak to my doctors in advance. Good thing, since my medical oncologist is a little prudish and did not agree that I was disabled. On the other hand, my radiation doctor was more than happy to stand behind my claim. I believe he was instrumental in getting my case approved. One love, Jackie
Posts.Title: SSDI jdootoo jennyboog

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2011 11:31AM jdootoo wrote: Lookingforward4more, I am happy to give you as much advice as I can. The most important thing is they are looking for PAIN. If you can convince them that you cannot work because it is too painful, that is your best bet. Social security has an official cut-off at IIIB, but I was able to get it at IIIA -- it should take 2 years to be approved in any case... maybe a few months at most. Also, if you are taking medication that makes it hard for you to focus or are on antidepressants, I would mention that to them as well. One thing that really helped me was to have all my paperwork prepared before I went in. I brought in copies of my path report, documents from the lymphedema therapist, PET results, etc. I wish you the best of luck, and pm me if you have any more questions. (although I am terrible at checking that folder!) One love, Jackie
Posts.Title: SSDI jdootoo jennyboog

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 06:29PM jdootoo wrote: Jennyboog, With IBC, you automatically qualify. Apply as so as you can, since SSDI has a 5 month waiting period. Best of luck and remember, you deserve this! SSDI was created for people like us, take advantage of it... One love, Jackie
Posts.Title: SSDI jdootoo jennyboog

Posts.Content: jdootoo wrote: I wanted to share my experience with my stage III sisters. I was able to get onto Disability the FIRST TIME I applied! I am at stage IIIA, but borderline IIIB because of some active lymph nodes that showed up on my PET scan after surgery.  Everybody at the Social Security office was very kind to me and pushed my application through in 3 weeks. So, it is possible! Please, if anyone would like advice on how to go through the process, I would be so happy to help. We have 2 small children, so this is so helpful to us. One love, Jackie  There's a natural mystic blowing through the air; If you listen carefully now you will hear. Posts.Title: Welcome to my Bizzaro World konakat CapeBretongirl

Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 10:12AM jdootoo wrote: When I first started posting, I felt the same way at times because this was my first experience with a forum. With time, though, I have gained a better understanding of how things work here, and I have found this forum to be an amazing resource from amazing women (and a few men). Sometimes people just don't have an answer for you... often times they just send hugs. I often just read posts and then put my hand to the avitar and say a silent prayer. Sometimes I do not have time to give a thoughtful reply and am just checking in.  Don't give up, there is a lot of love here. It may be helpful to just do some browsing for a while to find information and then post again when you are ready. ((((Amy)))) One love, Jackie
Posts.Title: very surprised at how unhelpful this site is amylynn1108 Moderators

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2012 06:48AM jdootoo wrote: Tropicmom: I applied for SSDI and, for some reason, my application was not processed. I called them, and they put it through right away because the person I spoke with was really nice and helpful. I was able to get on SSDI at stage III. If I ware you, I would call them, and keep calling until you get a kind and helpful person on the other line, or go down to the SS office and do the same thing. You should automatically qualify, and should be able to get accelerated benefits. Hiring a lawyer will definately help you, but you can do this yourself as well. Remember, SSDI was developed for people like us who really need it. Sometimes they get a little over zealous about turning people down because there is so much fraud. Stand up for your rights and get an agent on your side. I wish you the best, YOU DESERVE THIS HELP! Please keep us posted. One love, Jackie
Posts.Title: SS turned me down tropicmom Chickadee

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2010 02:10PM jdootoo wrote: You have a lot of rights for medical coverage because of the lobbying and fundraising done on behalf of breast cancer. I have Aetna insurance and they will send me a letter called a "Precertification/Preauthorization Nonparticipating Provider Request". I am sure all insurance companies have this. If there is on in-network specialist within a certain distance from you, they have to accept an out of network provider as in network. Hope this helps!
Posts.Title: A Moment of Rant khartoregon khartoregon

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2010 06:51PM jdootoo wrote: Patsy, I know this can feel overwhelming, but hang in there. I am 45 and was diagnosed the same way as you on my first mammogram. The needle biopsy for my lymph nodes came back negative and when I woke from surgery, I found out that 6/7 were positive and I had a 3cm tumor on one of my nodes. You will feel better once the drains come out and, from what I am told, chemo is a lot less scary once you start -- the anticipation of the unknown is hard. I start chemo on Monday. I think it is nice to keep all of our sisters in mind as we go through this, and I will keep you in mind.

Posts.Title: Hair story -- it finally happenened! jdootoo Annie62

Posts.Content: jdootoo wrote: I will be finishing my Herceptin treatments next month (hurray! ) and spoke with my Oncologist and PS about scheduling my exchange surgery. They both agreed that a PET scan is not necessary unless I want to have one done. First I thought I wanted a scan, just to know... should I have my port removed? should I be concerned about the few active cells found in my lymph nodes? should I be concerned about the 2 lung nodules that were too small to biopsy? Then I thought, no, it is better for me just to move forward and keep believing that I am NED. I thought it is also better not to know if I have had a recurrence, unless I start having symptoms. Now I am thinking maybe I should have the scan since both my DH and I are considering returning to school this year and the decisions we make might be altered by the outcome of the scan. I never thought I would have such a hard time making a decision about this. I am not sure if others have had these same concerns and/or worries, but if you have, I would love it if you would share your experiences with me. One love, Jackie  There's a natural mystic blowing through the air; If you listen carefully now you will hear. Posts.Content: jdootoo wrote: It was just a matter of time, really. I live in the city and went to sit on the benches outside of my building to do some knitting last night (we live on a major road). My 8 year old son comes running up to me, sits down and asks, "Mommy, did you forget something?" I asked him, "What do you mean?" He looks at me funny and says, "Um, your hair?" Sure enough, I was bald as the day I was born, happily knitting away in front of dozens of people! We laughed all the way back upstairs! One love, Jackie There's a natural mystic blowing through the air; If you listen carefully now you will hear. Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2012 03:17AM jdootoo wrote: Hi Jenny, this may be a long shot, but could it be Tinea Versicolor? I would have this pop up every few months for years from living in the Caribbean. I bought a product called "Versel" which is 2.5% Selenium Sulfide. This is the only product that finally wiped it out. It is known to have a cancer fighting properties as well, which has made me wonder about the relation between cancer and fungus. As an interesting sidenote, I also used this lotion on a skin growth that was on my bc side, right above where my lump was, and the growth disappeared completely in 3 days! Even my Oncologist found this interesting. Sending hugs and hope all goes well on tuesday. One love, Jackie

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2010 10:39PM jdootoo wrote: I also had Paget's, but had never even heard of it before I read my pathology report. In fact, I went in for a mammogram after I discovered a brownish-red discharge from one breast. I also had noticed a crusty rash. Go see a breast surgeon and ask to be tested for Paget's, this is the best way to know for sure. I wish I had gone in when I first started noticing symptoms. Best of luck to you! One love, Jackie
Posts.Title: possible pagets of nipple lillygirl35 feistybluegecko

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 06:16PM jdootoo wrote: My diagnosis was so detrimental to our finances that I get panic attacks when I walk past a bank or the mailbox. No kidding! Dealing with cancer affects so many facets of our lives... I hate when I get caught up in financial worries, but this is part of my "new normal". It is comforting to me to read how others struggle with the day to day issues that add stress onto our already stressful lives. All I hear from well meaning friends is how grateful I must feel that my health is good... I am grateful, but the other struggles in life continue and are pushed a little deeper because of my medical issues. Thanks for letting me rant, Jackie
Posts.Title: Emotional Issues From BC PTSD? Shanagirl SpunkyGirl

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2011 10:35PM jdootoo wrote: Hi Katie, my DH had a similar experience when he wrote a letter to then Senator Obama that was picked up by the media. He felt it was important to set the record straight when what was printed got off track and became negative. The attention dies down very quickly, so it is important to get your message across before the media moves on to other topics, if that is what you choose to do. The good thing about that is that, if you want to regain your privacy, within a week or so people will probably stop calling. I think it is great that your blog was picked up and I am going to read the article now! One love, Jackie
Posts.Title: I need advice. Non cancer related katie31 blondiex46

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2010 10:35AM jdootoo wrote: Hi Sara, I am 10 days out on my first treatment of TCH, every 3 weeks. I feel really good today, but felt similar to you for the first 4-5 days. What really helped me were 2 things: 1. Move around as much as you can. I found that I felt the same whether I was resting or mobile, but started to feel better after being up for 10 minutes or so. Of cours, rest when you need to. 2.  Eat as often as you can. I always felt better after eating, even when I wasn't hungry.  Hang in there, you will feel better soon!
Posts.Title: April 2010 starting chemo caltex_catlady kad22

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2010 03:42PM jdootoo wrote: Please add me to this thread. I started chemo on April 5, had a bi-lateral mastectome on March 5 and the lymph node biopsy came back positive for 6/7. I had gone under thinking my lymph nodes were clear after a needle biopsy. I will be doing TCH every 3 weeks for 6 treatments, then radiation and Herceptin for one year.  So far, the side effects of the chemo have not been that severe, I just felt really out of it and a little nauseous for about 4 days. I have heard that the second treatment can really kick you rump and I want to be prepared for that. Has anyone had that experience? My love and prayers to all of you...
Posts.Title: April 2010 starting chemo caltex_catlady kad22

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2010 09:56AM jdootoo wrote: I just went to see my PT for the first time yesterday and we talked about flying since I will be leaving for vacation on Tuesday. She said that it is important to wear a glove as well as the sleeve because, if your hand swells, the sleeve would need to come off, raising your risk for swelling in the arm. She also recommended wearing the sleeve for strenuous tasks. You may want to consider this for preventative measures. (Wish I had known that before!) Hope this helps and best of luck! One love, Jackie

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2011 01:52AM jdootoo wrote: I had some lumps in my arm soon after my MX. The doctors were very concerned that they were lymph nodes so they did a biopsy immediately. It turned out to be fatty necrosis, which is caused by fat tissue that loses it's blood source after surgery and dies and then is absorbed back into the body. I was surprised that I could potentially have positive nodes in my arm. How far are you out from surgery? One love, Jackie

Posts.Content: jdootoo wrote: I just had to share this story -- I find it so funny! My boys have been obsessed with the Christmas Shoes song for a couple of years, but I have always HATED it. Why? Let's see.. ...I mean, like who wouldn't give a few bucks to a kid who is trying to buy shoes for his mom who is dying? It's not like this is some sort of "life lesson" or "do-goodie" thing. It all seems kind of obvious to me. ...maybe it's because I live in New York, but if some kid is asking me for money to buy shoes for his mom, I am going to assume that he is scamming me and is going to buy cigarettes or something. ...when the day comes that I am on my deathbed, I sure as hell don't want a pair of shoes!!! Lol! Anyway, as soon as my kids picked up on how much I hate the song, they would run for the radio and turn it up full blast whenever the song would come on. They would sing it to me at the top of their lungs until I would bury my face in the couch with my hands over my ears, shouting for them to TURN IT OFF!! The we all laugh hysterically.  The funny thing is, they so don't get the irony of it all this year, and still play this game with me, totally clueless... God, I love them!! One love, Jackie  There's a natural mystic blowing through the air; If you listen carefully now you will hear. This could be the first trumpet, might as well be the last: Many more will have to suffer, Many more will have to die - don't ask me why. -- Bob Marley Dx 1/29/2010, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 6/7 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2010 10:57PM jdootoo wrote: Heyjude: I also had brownish discharge from my nipple with crustiness. I ended up having Paget's disease of the nipple. Most of the time Paget's indicates underlying IDC. Ask your BS for a mammogram and/or MRI as soon as possible. You may even want to switch to another BS if this was not recommended to you from the beginning. Best of luck to you. One love, Jackie

Posts.Content: May 29, 2011 04:41PM jdootoo wrote: Fearless One, from what I remember (after one year of chemo brain!) SSA would consider you disabled when you can no longer work, i.e. when you quit your job or went on disability. Then there is a 5 month waiting period before benefits kick in. I have heard, however, that you can get accelerated benefits at stage IV... can anyone clarify this? Worse yet, there is a 2 year waiting period before being eligible for Medicare. SSI is totally income based, though, and you would be eligible for that if you cannot work at all and have no income coming in. SSDI will deduct any SSI benefits from the amount you receive once that kicks in. It is confusing, and I think it is that way to discourage people from abusing the system. When I went in for my interview, the people at SSA were very nice to me and very helpful. I think they want to help the people who really need it. Don't worry, there is always help available for basic living expenses. We ended up having to file bankruptcy because I could not work last summer (I worked freelance and was at doctor appointments 3-4 times a week, leaving me with no time to work). It sucks, it is frustrating, but it is what it is.  (((hugs)))) Jackie
Posts.Title: Stage 3 and social security disability benefits bak94 pupfoster1

Posts.Content: May 30, 2011 08:17AM jdootoo wrote: Fearless One: I have a close friend who has a severe heart condition, sort of like a viral infection of the heart. She has a pacemaker and has been on death's bed 3 times. Last month she died for a few minutes and was brought back to life. She had to convince SSA that she couldn't cook for her family or do housework, because they felt if she could do these things, she could work. Really messed up, they were charging rent on credit cards before SSDI kicked in. I wish they would fix the system, too. Blah! One love, Jackie

Posts.Content: May 28, 2011 01:15PM jdootoo wrote: In New York they always do an interview, though they can do it over the phone under special circumstances. You should apply right away since I think they start your 5 month waiting period from application date. You can apply online.  I remember giving a form to my doctor... I chose which doctor, and spoke with him about my situation. I think it is a good idea to do this so you are sure your doctor is on your side. My medical oncologist was not interested in helping me get the SSDI as her feeling was that I would be fine after treatment. My radiation oncologist, however, was more than happy to help me out since he felt it would be better for me not to work for a while. Hope this helps... One love, Jackie
Posts.Title: Stage 3 and social security disability benefits bak94 pupfoster1

Posts.Content: May 29, 2011 12:30AM jdootoo wrote: The 5 month waiting period starts from the date of application. I applied in March, 2010 and my application got lost in the shuffle. When I called the SSA office in September, they set up an appointment for me right away, then approved me within 2 weeks. The first payment I received was backpaid from August, 5 months after I applied.  Also, you are allowed to make up to 16k a year and still receive payments. Jennyboog: you should apply right away too! One love, Jackie p.s. I have a good friend who is a social worker, and she told me that all they want to hear about is pain, side effects from meds, and mental illness. You will need to find a way to convince SSA that you cannot work due to one of these three reasons. Good luck everyone! Please feel free to pm me with questions.
Posts.Title: Stage 3 and social security disability benefits bak94 pupfoster1

Posts.Content: May 29, 2011 11:30AM jdootoo wrote: Thanks Fearless One... SSA decides when your disability began, usually the date they determine you are no longer able to work. I was counting backward from my 5 month waiting period. I remembered later that during my interview, SSA had determined that I was no longer able to work at the time that I applied. Keep the good information coming! This is a great thread as it is important for everyone to know what to expect. I hope more sistahs who are on SSDI will chime in with advice!  One love, Jackie

Posts.Content: May 28, 2011 11:10AM jdootoo wrote: I was approved for SSDI at stage IIIA. I was thrilled that they approved me, but still a little freaked out about how easy it was... what does that mean? Don't let that stop you from applying, though, and the earlier you apply, the better. From what I understand, as long as you are unable to work now, it shouldn't matter how much money you making at the job (the Fearless One could be right about that).  You should automatically qualify, and I think that knowledge will be helpful for you at the interview. When you do go in, make sure you have all of your paperwork in order and talk to your doctors in advance, since Social Security will be interviewing them. I did this, and I think that is why I was approved so easily. The thing you will want to do is to convince Social Security that you cannot work right now due to pain, side affects from medication, or mental illness.  Good luck, and let me know if you have more questions. One love, Jackie
Posts.Title: Stage 3 and social security disability benefits bak94 pupfoster1
